subsection.title: Horizontal and Vertical Lines
subsection.p: Two special cases of linear equations are worth noting. First, an equation such as y=4 can be thought of as an equation in two variables, 0x+y=4 For each value of x, this equation assigns the value \alert{4} to y. Thus, any ordered pair of the form (x,4) is a solution of the equation. For example, (-1,\alert{4}),~~(2,\alert{4})~~\text{and}~~(4,\alert{4}) are all solutions of the equation. If we draw a straight line through these points, we obtain the horizontal line shown at left below.

The other special case of a linear equation is of the type x=3, or x+0y=3 Here, only one value is permissible for x, namely \alert{3}, while any value may be assigned to y. Any ordered pair of the form (3,y) is a solution of this equation. If we choose two solutions, say (\alert{3},1) and (\alert{3},3), and draw a straight line through these two points, we have the vertical line shown at right above. In general, we have the following results.

assemblage.p: The graph of ~~x=k~~ (k a constant) is a vertical line.
The graph of ~~y=k~~ (k a constant) is a horizontal line.

subsection.p: Now let's compute the slopes of the two lines in the previous example. Choose two points on the graph of y=2, say (-5,2) and (4,2). Use these points to compute the slope. m=\dfrac{y_2-y_1}{x_2-x_1}=\dfrac{2-2}{4-(-5)}=\dfrac{0}{9}=0 The slope of the horizontal line y=2 is zero. In fact, the slope of any horizontal line is zero, because the y -coordinates of all the points on the line are equal. Thus m=\dfrac{y_2-y_1}{x_2-x_1}=\dfrac{0}{x_2-x_1}=0 On a vertical line, the x-coordinates of all the points are equal. For example, two points on the line x=-3 are (-3,1) and (-3,6). Using these points to compute the slope, we find m=\dfrac{y_2-y_1}{x_2-x_1}=\dfrac{6-1}{-3-(-3)}=\dfrac{5}{0} which is undefined. The slope of any vertical line is undefined because the expression x_2-x_1 equals zero.

assemblage.p: The slope of a horizontal line is zero.
The slope of a vertical line is undefined.

subsection.title: Parallel and Perpendicular Lines
subsection.p:
Consider the graphs of the equations
y=\dfrac{2}{3}x-4 y=\dfrac{2}{3}x+2 shown below.
The lines have the same slope, \dfrac{2}{3}, but different y-intercepts. Because slope measures the steepness or inclination of a line, lines with the same slope are parallel.

assemblage.p: Two lines with slopes m_1 and m_2 are parallel if and only if m_1=m_2.

statement.p: Are the graphs of the equations 3x+6y=6 and y=-\dfrac{1}{2}x+5 parallel?

subsection.p:
Now consider the graphs of the equations
y=\dfrac{2}{3}x-2 y=-\dfrac{3}{2}x+3 shown below.

assemblage.p: Two lines with slopes m_1 and m_2 are perpendicular if m_2=\dfrac{-1}{m_1}.

subsection.p: We say that m_2 is the negative reciprocal of m_1.

statement.p: Are the graphs of 3x-5y=5 and 2y=\dfrac{10}{3}x+3 perpendicular?

solution.p: We find the slope of each line by putting the equations into slope-intercept form. For the first line, \begin{aligned}[t] 5y \amp = 3x-5 \amp \amp \blert{\text{Divide both sides by}~ 5.}\\ y \amp = \dfrac{3}{5}x - 1\\ \end{aligned} so m_1=\dfrac{3}{5}. For the second line, y=\dfrac{5}{3}x+\dfrac{3}{2}, so m_2=\dfrac{5}{3}. Now, the negative reciprocal of m_1 is \dfrac{-1}{m_1}=\dfrac{-1}{\dfrac{3}{5}}=\dfrac{-5}{3} but m_2=\dfrac{5}{3}. Thus, m_2 \not= \dfrac{-1}{m_1}, so the lines are not perpendicular.

subsection.title: Applications to Geometry
subsection.p: These relationships for the slopes of parallel and perpendicular lines can help us solve numerous geometric problems.

statement.p: Show that the triangle with vertices A(0,8),~B(6,2),~ and C(-4,4) shown below is a right triangle.

solution.p: We will show that two of the sides of the triangle are perpendicular. The line segment \overline{AB} has slope m_1 = \dfrac{2-8}{6-0} = \dfrac{-6}{6} = -1 and the line segment \overline{AC} has slope m_2 = \dfrac{4-8}{-4-0} = \dfrac{-4}{-4} = 1 Because \dfrac{-1}{m_1} = \dfrac{-1}{-1} = 1 = m_2, the sides \overline{AB} and \overline{AC} are perpendicular, and the triangle is a right triangle.

subsection.p: Consider the graph of 4x-2y=6 shown below.

Can we find the equation of the line that is parallel to this line, but passes through the point (1,4)? If we can find the slope of the desired line, we can use the slope-intercept formula to find its equation.

Now because the line we want is parallel to the given line, they must have the same slope. To find the slope of the given line, we write its equation in slope-intercept form: \begin{aligned}[t] 4x-2y \amp = 6 \amp \amp \blert{\text{Subtract}~4x~\text{from both sides.}}\\ -2y \amp = -4x+6 \amp \amp\ \blert{\text{Divide both sides by}~-2.}\\ y \amp = 2x-3\\ \end{aligned} The slope of the given line is 2. Because the unknown line is parallel to this line, its slope is also 2. Now we know the slope of the desired line, m=2, and one point on the line, (1,4). Substituting these values into the point-slope formula will give us the equation. \begin{aligned}[t] y-y_1 \amp = m(x-x_1)\\ y-\alert{4} \amp = \alert{2}(x-\alert{1}) \amp \amp \blert{\text{Apply the distributive law.}}\\ y-4\amp = 2x-2 \amp \amp \blert{\text{Add 4 to both sides.}}\\ y\amp = 2x+2 \end{aligned}

statement.p: Find an equation for the line that passes through the point (1,4) and is perpendicular to the line 4x-2y=6.

solution.p: We follow the same strategy as in the discussion above: First find the slope of the desired line, then use the point-slope formula to write its equation.

The line we want is perpendicular to the given line, so its slope is the negative reciprocal of m_1=2, the slope of the given line. Thus m_2 = \dfrac{-1}{m_1} = \dfrac{-1}{2} Now we use the point-slope formula with m_2= \dfrac{-1}{2} and (x_1,y_1)=(1,4). \begin{aligned}[t] y-y_1 \amp = m(x-x_1)\\ y-\alert{4} \amp = \alert{\dfrac{-1}{2}}(x-\alert{1}) \amp \amp \blert{\text{Apply the distributive law.}}\\ y-4\amp = \dfrac{-1}{2}x+\dfrac{1}{2} \amp \amp \blert{\text{Add 4 to both sides.}}\\ y\amp = \dfrac{-1}{2}x+\dfrac{9}{2} \amp \amp \blert{\dfrac{1}{2}+4 = \dfrac{1}{2}+\dfrac{8}{2}=\dfrac{9}{2}}\\ \end{aligned} The given line and the perpendicular line are shown below.
